data.text: Bicycling Touring Rashes: What Is the Treatment?

Bicycling touring rashes. Ok, let‚Äôs chat about rashes. On top of everything yesterday with my tire, I discovered two nasty rashes on inside thighs near an important body part. I was wearing mountain bike shorts with liner and it was very humid. I know what I need to do but would like to hear from the pros‚Ä¶ How do you combat rashes? I‚Äôm sure others experience this and could learn from you guys. Me personally, I‚Äôm going to wear regular spandex until this gets resolved. I have A&D ointment to help clear it up and I will be in a hotel tonight to soak in tub and dry out a bit. What‚Äôs your remedy?
Shower immediately after riding then hand sanitizer on those areas then let dry. This has solved what used to be a big problem for me.
data.author: Brent Irvine

data.text: I use AD pre ride.
data.author: Karen McKenna

data.text: Apply a Liberal dollop of Bag Balm to all skin between the legs before long rides.
data.author: Chris Balduc

data.text: My remedy, luckily, has always been prevention. I have been touring fully loaded basically since 2018. 28,000+ miles and I have never had an issue. I wear Lululemon shorts with a liner and ride on a Brooks saddle. This has always worked for me and I will continue until it doesn‚Äôt.
data.author: Scott Sharick

data.text: Some type of lubricant in the crutch every morning before you start the days riding and you will be ok , when I started touring i wasn't aware of the damage that can be done to the skin bit now understand
data.author: Vin Carter

data.text: cheap Vaseline or non brand alternative can help
data.author: Jon France

data.text: yes Vaseline or something that will last
data.author: Vin Carter

data.text: Chamois butter is the key to prevention
data.author: Kevin Voll

data.text: A rash, as in a skin reaction? Or a sore, created from rubbing??
data.author: Russ McCoy

data.text: I suffered the same affliction when I rode the Blue Ridge Parkway in August 1996. Among Swedish hikers I believe it's known as "infantry fire" since the combination of long marches and warm clothes often causes it. In my case, the remedy turned out very simple. Different underwear! I normally wear Jockey-style briefs (even when cycling since I ride a recumbent and don't need padding) but a switch to boxer shorts was all I needed. The tiny legs on the boxers completely got rid of the chafing.
data.author: Torsten Lif

data.text: The most important aspect of long distance bicycle riding is comfort. I NEVER get body issues with this setup‚Ä¶.. Especially with a Cloud9 seat‚Ä¶‚Ä¶
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text: I use a and d ointment as a preventative when I ride long miles in heat and humidity
data.author: Michelle Blackman

data.text: I'd use Epson salt in the bath. That AD ointment looks cool. I've used Burts baby ointment. I'd look at the tilt of your saddle, and height, and fore/aft adjustment. But mostly the tilt. Maybe pointing the nose down a little. Very small adjustments make a big difference there. I get mine to where I almost feel like I'm going to slide off forward. Maybe especially if you have low handlebars. An alternative might be flipping the stem over, especially if you also have problems with hand numbness. But personally I do like to ride a little bit aero so tilting the saddle seems to work best for me. Oh yeah, the washing right after riding thing is huge. If nothing else have some wipes available for asap cleaning.
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: For me, the key is to stay dry and clean. Quick drying shorts and underwear that are thin and have no seams. Walk a bit every hour. Stand and dry out on any downhills I can. Change underwear during the ride and clean the used ones in some of the bathrooms I come across, especially when it's really hot. Lather up with an available cream after the days ride.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: Lycra shorts without underwear. You can wear your MTB shorts over it if you don't want to look like a bike racer
data.author: Gert Pellin

data.text: Padded bike shorts that get changed regularly while on tour. Monkey-Butt anti-chafe powder is also key. If you have body parts that are rubbing together for some reason, a bit of vaseline is key.
data.author: Bob Breeze

data.text: Chamois cream as a preventative. In a pinch, sudocrem will do. Some find Assos a bit "minty" but some like that. For treatment, clean and dry and germolene, followed by Assos Skin repair cream then sudocrem baby stuff.
data.author: Pete Nightingale

data.text: "Minty"! It's not lip balm...
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text: I find Desitin helpful for dealing with occasional sores, but still need to address the root cause to prevent further irritation. Often that is handled by a slight saddle adjustment, which most likely resulted from having to remove the saddle recently. I love my Brooks Flyer, but it does need to be in the exact right spot.
data.author: Bob Sinko

data.text: There are different types of rash. Friction/overly moist skin is the most common. There are lots of creams for this and products like Glide. There are also fungal rashes, and some caused by bacterial infection These sound gross but are pretty common too. There are OTC creams for this too, which are worth checking out if the usual bum butter or diaper cream don't fix your rash. Just talk to a pharmacist. The other thing that can get neglected on tour is personal hygiene. It is really important to wash you bits at least once per day.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: keep things extremely clean before applying something like chamois butt'r or body glid or similar products.. after your ride when you're relaxing, get a good shower, apply a bit of hydrocortisone, and something like anti-monkey-butt powder or caldesene powder. stick with normal spandex for the time being because wearing a liner or wearing a pair of shorts over the spandex will hold moisture in and defeat the purposes of the spandex wicking the sweat away from your body.
data.author: Cameron A. Kabinoff

data.text: I use a little jock itch cream every morning and do not have the problem (anymore). Just the otc house brand seems to work fine. I discovered this on a two month tour about week two after there was, not to get gross, blood and of course pain. It cleared it up in a day or two and now I use it as a preventative.
data.author: James Schoettgen

data.text: Desitin, a little goes a long ways.
data.author: Chuck Butler

data.text: Chamois Butter
data.author: Lynne Meredith

data.text: I don't use chamois cream for riding, but I have a cream for babie' s diapers rash. You get to your camp or hotel, shower and wash very well carefully dry and...the most important point...let it air dry...what I mean, I wear in camp loose short, no undies and before sleep, put on cream and let it "breath" also if you can no undies and keep the rash dry. For me works fine. Next day riding try to clean and dry it and if you have put some cream. Hope gets better!
data.author: Olie Gr√∏nn

data.text: Hoo haa ride glide works for me
data.author: Gaynor Hamilton

data.text: I don't suffer with anything since I changed my saddle to a Brooks Flyer and tight cotton leggings with no underwear..
data.author: Amanda Kruger

data.text: Professional bike fitting first.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: Make sure seat is properly adjusted. Height and angle. If your rocking when you pedal that will increase chafing. Also chamois butter of some type
data.author: Jesse Justice

data.text: I ride around 7000 km/yr in jeans and normal underwear. Another 3000 km in normal shorts... No skin problems.
data.author: Halbe Klijnstra

data.text: Same issue here in thailand. It could be you seat it too wide but I'm betting if you lower you seat a little it will help. Try lowering the seat maybe 2-3mm. If it helps then consider moving the seat back 1mm if you want to get back to the prior pedal to seat distance for your leg reach.
data.author: Stephen Lodewick

data.text: Coconut oil works for me and has many uses ü••
data.author: Justin Ashcroft

data.text: was wondering about coconut oil.
data.author: Glenn Tatum

data.text: Aquaphor
data.author: Thomas Olsen

data.text: Not sure what your experience has been so far, but it might be worth revisiting your saddle. I had a similar problem in that the muscles in my legs would sweep against the side of my old saddle. I tried a couple of new ones and settled on a Selle SMP which allows my legs to move without sweeping against it. You may need to try a couple yourself, but it‚Äôs worth a try. You don‚Äôt need a full professional bike fit necessarily, but visit a bike shop, get a saddle fitting, try several brands and see what solves the problem. It may take a longer time rather than being a quick fix but it‚Äôs really worth it.
data.author: Ken Neth

data.text: Chamois cr√®me is recommended but I would start with the root cause. Is the saddle the wrong saddle for you
data.author: Ken Boutilier

data.text: Squats
data.author: Ctd Thanh Diep

data.text: Suck it up buttercup I don‚Äôt use softeners and that was the best choice there‚Äôs a reason why guitarists have calluses on their fingersÔøº
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: Brooks saddle, drop the padded shorts. No more rash.
data.author: R.H. Southcott

data.text: Bag balm. Farmers Use it on cow teats
data.author: Terrence Gray

data.text: Sudocrem morning noon and night for really sore nether regions, and just in the morning if prevention is the strategy
data.author: David Lee

data.text: Use wetwipes frequently during the day. And some cooling ointment
data.author: Anders Hansen

data.text: I have always worn ‚Äúracer‚Äù style padded spandex. As soon as the day‚Äôs riding is finished, I get out of my riding shorts and at a minimum wash and dry my crotch/butt area. I carry two pair of cycling shorts so I can wash one pair every evening and wear the dry pair the next day. If I do start developing any rash, I nip it in the bud with a little A&D, Boudreaux‚Äôs Butt cream, or whatever rash ointment I can find.
data.author: Bill Funderburk

data.text: Brooks saddle and TWO pair of shorts‚Ä¶ ALWAYS. Never had a rash.
data.author: Chris Rumbelow

data.text: Solution‚Ä¶Model B-17. Comfortable > 80 miles.
data.author: Michael Lee Woodard

data.text: Have you considered the possibility that your seat might be poorly placed? Google: 'Bike Fitting' there's some fairly good videos. I have an ancient copy of Zin's that is everything; it's good to have a strong understanding how to adjust your bike for comfort; particularly, if you hope to ride all day. ;-) And, I've used a Brooks saddle, b-17 for 35 years, I've broken three... Its amazing when everything works together so all there is is the ride.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: Oh, and I oftentimes don't wear padded shorts or something rather thin....I don't like clothing that screams "I'm a cyclist"....I like functional clothing that is comfortable on my body and casual in public.
data.author: Samuel Lea

data.text: Bag Balm üíØüíØüíØ
data.author: Ron Taylor

data.text: A better seat. I've toured before with bike padded shorts and no matter what I did still occasionally got saddle sores. Then I tried a new seat that was more comfortable and never wear padded shorts and have fewer problems. And don't buy the whole leather seats are better BS I've tried the leather saddles and I can tell you they definitely are not for everyone! As for the rash buy a good natural salve and apply it at night before bed. Should clear up in a day or so As for the rare occurrence where I'm sweating a lot and have a problem. I stop and wipe down with a wet wipe down there to get rid of salts. On a tour rinse/wash your shorts as often as possible
data.author: Nick Quine

data.text: B-17 brooks and bum butter
data.author: Richard Bould
Richard Bould

data.text: For normal chafing I will use A&D ointment. Tea tree oil is supposed to be great to because it kills the bacteria that leads to infection.
data.author: Craig Turner

data.text: Wash yourself and any clothes that are next to your skin thoroughly. I've toured in very hot and humid climates, wearing padded cycling shorts for days on end and I've never had any problems with rashes etc. Or maybe the bugs just don't like me! üòâ
data.author: Huw Thomas
